channel.title: Encryption Removal
channel.description:
Hi, my char files are encrypted and I need to know how to unencrypt them. Is there anyway to do that? Thanks,
Nick

item.title: Encryption Removal
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

I was reading a book about hashes and one way algorithms, (skimming through it though) and from what I read, it said that when a password is hashed using a one way algorithm, there is no way to decrypt it like that. (Hence one-way) The way they use the hashes is that when a user types the password into the login box, it encrypts the password that they sent, and checks it against the encrypted password in the database. If the encrypted passwords match, they are logged in.

Read full topic

item.title: Encryption Removal
item.dc:creator: @deathschaos9 DeathsChaos9
item.description:
@deathschaos9 wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:5, topic:347481”][quote author=deathschaos9 link=topic=443859.msg3259324#msg3259324 date=1278376266]

You can remove the encryption to prevent new password from being encrypted, but you cannot decrypt MD5.

Yes you can? If you could not decrypt it, then there would be no use for encryption.

The MD5 hash cannot be decrypted because it is a hash.

Hash - a special form of encryption often used for passwords, that uses a one-way algorithm

[/quote]

If it actually was one-way, then why would we use it. Sure, we could hash the password being attempted with, and then compare the two, but it seems pointless to me.

Also, look at this. I used it for a game i am working on. So I could test to see if I can crack the hashing method, without using MD5 itself, but so I can make a branch of it.

http://www.md5decrypter.co.uk/[/quote]
I’ve never found the MD5 hash useful, but than again, I don’t do anything that would need encryption to begin with.
Anyway, that website doesn’t decrypt the hash, it just checks its database to see if someones submitted the unencrypted hash. They take random words and numbers and combine them, put them into their database, and encrypt it. When someone enters a hash that matches a hash in their database, it returns the string that they entered before encryption(Or something like that)
It’s just not possible to decrypt the MD5 hash. I’m not trying to fight with you or anything, but its the truth.

Read full topic

item.title: Encryption Removal
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“deathschaos9, post:4, topic:347481”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=443859.msg3259318#msg3259318 date=1278375900]

You can remove the encryption to prevent new password from being encrypted, but you cannot decrypt MD5.

Yes you can? If you could not decrypt it, then there would be no use for encryption.
[/quote]
The MD5 hash cannot be decrypted because it is a hash.

Hash - a special form of encryption often used for passwords, that uses a one-way algorithm[/quote]

If it actually was one-way, then why would we use it. Sure, we could hash the password being attempted with, and then compare the two, but it seems pointless to me.

Also, look at this. I used it for a game i am working on. So I could test to see if I can crack the hashing method, without using MD5 itself, but so I can make a branch of it.

http://www.md5decrypter.co.uk/

Read full topic

item.title: Encryption Removal
item.dc:creator: @deathschaos9 DeathsChaos9
item.description:
@deathschaos9 wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:3, topic:347481”][quote author=deathschaos9 link=topic=443859.msg3259258#msg3259258 date=1278371946]
You can remove the encryption to prevent new password from being encrypted, but you cannot decrypt MD5.
[/quote]
Yes you can? If you could not decrypt it, then there would be no use for encryption.[/quote]
The MD5 hash cannot be decrypted because it is a hash.

Hash - a special form of encryption often used for passwords, that uses a [i]one-way algorithm[/i]

Read full topic

item.title: Encryption Removal
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

deathschaos9:

You can remove the encryption to prevent new password from being encrypted, but you cannot decrypt MD5.

Yes you can? If you could not decrypt it, then there would be no use for encryption.

@TOPIC - The method most servers use, to get the string, is passHash. To find the method, just search for:

public string passHash

Should be in client.java somewhere. There are 2 ways of getting rid of it.
[ul][li]Just comment out everything except the very last return.[/li]
[li]Or, find where it is being called in client.java, and remove it from that. Both are fairly simple methods.[/li][/ul]

NOTE: Players will not be able to login since their saved password is encrypted. I suggest making an email for them to email you at to get their password reset.

Read full topic
